item.title: Charles Griffes - Five Poems of Ancient China and Japan (1917)
item.description: [[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]] - between 1916-1917, #Griffes' roots in European-style composition began to give way to influences from Japan and China these are settings of five oriental poems as orchestral art songs (initially scored for voice and piano), based on pentatonic and six-tone scales

item.title: Charles Griffes - Piano Sonata (1917-18)
item.description: [[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]] — shows a break from style and approach of his earlier works, being dissonant and devoid of programme or descriptive title, yet in three movements with the 1st and 3rd being clearly in sonata form, in a unique fusion of both tradition and the new

item.title: Charles Griffes - Sho-jo (1917)
item.description: [[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]] - a Japanese pantomime in one scene commissioned for ballet that include harmonies suggesting quarter-tones

item.title: Charles Griffes - The Pleasure-Dome of Kubla Khan (1919)
item.description: [[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]] - originally written for piano and later prepared for orchestra, this is the best-known oriental work by Griffes

item.title: Charles Griffes - Three Preludes for piano (1919)
item.description: [[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]] — similar in style to the Piano sonata, but are miniature works of 32 bars or less some integration of Impressionist and Oriental influences into his own unique language towards the end, though the different works across time demonstrate different influences

item.description: [[EUROPEAN LINK]] - from around 1911 (4 years after returning to USA from Germany) to 1917, Griffes began to compose in an impressionistic style and frequently gave descriptive titles to his works https://www.

item.title: Samuel Barber - Knoxville, Summer of 1915 (1947)
item.description: in depicting a summer evening in Tennessee through the eyes of a young boy, Barber incorporates native elements ([[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]]) this work could be considered most American ([[DISTINCTIVE AMERICAN VOICE]]) amongst Barber’s output

item.title: Samuel Barber - Piano Concerto (1962)
item.description: Commissioned by Schirmer in 1959 in honour of the company’s 100th anniversary, written with pianist John Browning in mind. The piano concerto won Barber his second Pulitzer Prize (the first had been given for his opera Vanessa)

item.description: [[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]] — Barber’s unique eclecticism might show influence of European Romanticism ([[EUROPEAN LINK]]), but he was not seeking to replicate it but to develop his own style For instance, https://www.

item.description: The symphony encompasses African-American music elements ([[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]]) within the traditional framework of a European four-movement symphony ([[EUROPEAN LINK]]) https://www.

item.title: William Grant Still - And They Lynched Him on a Tree (1940)
item.description: [[impact of SOCIO-CULTURAL EVENTS]] — Written for double chorus, identified in the score as “White Crowd” and “Negro Men and Women” Oratorio presenting strong social commentary against racism, portraying the lynching of a black man who had been found guilty and jailed for some unspecified crime.

item.title: William Grant Still - From the Black Belt (1926)
item.description: Suite for orchestra in seven short movements, each a characteristic sketch that presents a clear programme relating to the given subtitle, comprising lyrical melodies and demonstrating influences from African-American music ([[ECLECTICISM; synthesis of musical styles & genres]]) Li’l Scamp Honeysuckle Dance Mah Bones is Creakin Blue Brown Girl Clap Yo’ Han’s
